questiontext.text:
Exercise

Decide which of the following pairs of events (\(A\) and \(B\)) arising from the experiments described are mutually exclusive.

  1. Two cards are drawn from a pack:
    \(A=\) a red card is drawn.
    \(B=\) a picture card is drawn.
    \(A\) and \(B\) are [[2]]
  2. A participant is recruited to a clinical trial who is randomly assigned to receive one of two treatments:
    \(A=\) the participant receives a placebo.
    \(B=\) the participant receives the experimental treatment.
    \(A\) and \(B\) are [[1]]
  3. A box contains \(20\) nuts. Some have a metric thread, some have a British Standard Fine (BSF) thread and some have a  British Standard Whitworth (BSW) thread.
    \(    A=\) first nut picked out of the box is BSF.
    \(B=\) second nut picked out of the box is metric.
    \(A\) and \(B\) are [[2]]

generalfeedback.text:
1. It is possible to draw a red picture card (e.g. Jack of hearts) meaning that events \(A\) and \(B\) are not mutually exclusive.
  2. A participant is randomly assigned to either the placebo or the experimental treatment, never both. This means that events \(A\) and \(B\) are mutually exclusive.
  3. As the box contains at least one of the three types if nuts, there is a non-zero probability of selecting one that is BSF and another that is metric. Therefore events \(A\) and \(B\) are not mutually exclusive.
